head.title: Lessons From the Jobs of Summer

hedline.hl1: Lessons From the Jobs of Summer

abstract.p: David Stewart letter responds to June 18 front-page article on young people's reluctance to take summer jobs; cites changes in society; drawing

block.p: The reason that fewer young people take summer jobs now (front page, June 18) has less to do with affluence and more to do with large changes in our society. I knew rich kids in the 1960's and 70's who took summer jobs in construction or as lifeguards because their parents, who were Depression children, wanted to instill certain values. Also, white-collar jobs were a smaller part of our economy then.

Also, white-collar jobs were a smaller part of our economy then.
Attitudes about college have changed, too. In the past, not everyone thought it was necessary to go to Harvard, so fewer high school students felt they needed to add to their resumes.
